articles.headline: Market Turmoil Prompts New Speculation on the Fed’s Timetable
articles.snippet: William C. Dudley said the case for an interest rate increase next month had become “less compelling."
articles.abstract: William C. Dudley said the case for an interest rate increase next month had become “less compelling."
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Turmoil in global financial markets has reduced the chances the Federal Reserve will raise its benchmark interest rate in September, a senior Fed policy maker said on Wednesday, but the possibility of a rate increase remains on the table, provided markets regain balance and economic problems in other countries do not disrupt the slow but steady performance of the domestic economy.

articles.headline: Walmart to End Sales of Assault-Style Rifles in U.S. Stores
articles.snippet: The retailer will stop selling modern sporting rifles, which are similar to the AR-15 assault rifle, which has been used in prominent mass shootings.
articles.abstract: The retailer will stop selling modern sporting rifles, which are similar to the AR-15 assault rifle, which has been used in prominent mass shootings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Walmart said on Wednesday that it would no longer sell high-powered rifles in its stores in the United States. The decision followed years of public pressure on the retailer to stop selling some of the most lethal weapons associated with many of the nation’s mass shootings.

articles.headline: China Falters, and the Global Economy Is Forced to Adapt
articles.snippet: With deepening economic fears about China, multinational corporations and countries are having to respond to a new reality as a once sure bet becomes uncertain.
articles.abstract: With deepening economic fears about China, multinational corporations and countries are having to respond to a new reality as a once sure bet becomes uncertain.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The commodities giant BHP Billiton spent heavily for years, mining iron ore across Australia, digging for copper in Chile, and pumping oil off the coast of Trinidad. The company could be confident in its direction as commodities orders surged from its biggest and best customer, China.

articles.headline: World Markets Jump as Investors Seek Signals in the Noise
articles.snippet: The S.&P. 500 and the Dow rose strongly and the Nasdaq turned positive for the year as better economic news buoyed trading.
articles.abstract: The S.&P. 500 and the Dow rose strongly and the Nasdaq turned positive for the year as better economic news buoyed trading.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every major stock market in the world soared higher on Thursday, rebounding from the lows they had hit earlier in the week.

articles.headline: Ukraine and Top Creditors Agree to Restructure $18 Billion in Foreign Debt
articles.snippet: The deal would write off 20 percent of the country’s overseas obligations and go far to help avoid a drawn-out, Greek-style negotiation with large bondholders.
articles.abstract: The deal would write off 20 percent of the country’s overseas obligations and go far to help avoid a drawn-out, Greek-style negotiation with large bondholders.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ukraine and its main creditors agreed on Thursday to restructure $18 billion of the country’s foreign debt, in a rare deal between bond funds and a wobbly, emerging-market government.

articles.headline: Grisly Discovery in Migrant Crisis Shocks Europe
articles.snippet: A truck filled with the decomposing bodies of migrants was found in Austria as European leaders were meeting nearby to devise ways to cope with the migration crisis.
articles.abstract: A truck filled with the decomposing bodies of migrants was found in Austria as European leaders were meeting nearby to devise ways to cope with the migration crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENNA — The legions of desperate migrants fleeing war and mayhem in the Middle East and Africa have long known they were risking harm from unscrupulous smugglers and death at sea to reach the safety of Europe. But it became shockingly clear on Thursday that they now face the same dangers within Europe’s own borders.
articles.byline: By Alison Smale and Melissa Eddy

articles.headline: As Economies Gasp Globally, U.S. Growth Quickens
articles.snippet: The U.S., long considered the tortoise in the world economy, continues to chug along, while the onetime hares in Asia, South America and elsewhere are flagging.
articles.abstract: The U.S., long considered the tortoise in the world economy, continues to chug along, while the onetime hares in Asia, South America and elsewhere are flagging.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, the United States was considered the tortoise of the world economy, at least in comparison to emerging powers like China and Brazil.
